item.title: Biden Needs More Empathy on the Economy, Democrats Say
item.description: The president often touts strong jobs numbers, even as voters care far more about inflation.

item.title: Dozens Killed in Israeli Airstrike on Rafah
item.description: The attack in the southern border city late Sunday killed 35 civilians, according to Palestinian health authorities.

item.title: Dollar's Gains Are Limited Due to Broad Reduction in Rate-Cut Expectations
item.description: The dollar is struggling to recover from recent losses as expectations of interest-rate cuts were scaled back in other countries as well as the U.S., UniCredit said.

item.title: Elon Musk's xAI to Raise $6 Billion in Latest Fundraising Round
item.description: The competitor to OpenAI is looking to invest more in research and development amid fierce competition in the burgeoning sector.

item.title: Bond Markets Expected to Start the Week at Slow Pace
item.description: Government bond markets were off to a slow start given U.K. and U.S. holidays, Commerzbank said, and following Germany’s Ifo business sentiment data this morning, inflation data later this week will also provide key input ahead of the ECB’s rate decision on June 6, where a 25 basis point rate cut is nearly a done deal.

item.title: Gold Prices Drift Higher Ahead of U.S. Inflation Data
item.description: Gold futures nudged higher, with the focus shifting to the next U.S. PCE price index release, the Federal Reserve’s preferred measure of inflation.

item.title: German Business Sentiment Fails to Improve
item.description: The Ifo business-climate index was unchanged in May, against expectations for an uptick, though firms did set out a more optimistic outlook for the months ahead.

item.title: Oil Edges Higher as Market Awaits OPEC+ Policy Decision
item.description: Oil prices edged higher, with all eyes on OPEC+’s upcoming decision on production cuts, with the cartel and its allies expected to fully roll over supply curbs at least into the third quarter of the year.

item.title: China Evergrande's EV Unit Shares Soar on Potential Investor Support
item.description: Shares of China Evergrande Group’s electric-vehicle unit surged, fueled by optimism that some businesses may survive despite the property giant’s liquidation.

item.title: Alstom to Raise $1 Billion in Discounted Share Capital Increase
item.description: The move by Alstom is the final step in its €2 billion deleveraging plan that also included asset divestments and a bond placement.

item.title: Nikkei Rises as 10-Year JGB Yield Hits 12-Year High
item.description: The Nikkei closed up 0.7% led by gains in financial stocks, as the 10-year Japanese government bond yield hit a 12-year high.

item.title: ECB's Lane Says Way Clear for Rate Cuts
item.description: The eurozone’s inflation rate and the pace of wage rises are slowing gradually, paving the way for possible rate cuts after a first reduction in borrowing costs next month, the ECB’s chief economist said.

item.title: U.S. Opposes European Plan to Censure Iran Over Nuclear Work
item.description: Washington is pressing European countries not to stoke tension with Iran at a coming U.N. atomic agency meeting.

item.title: At Least 17 Killed in Southern Storms as Severe Weather Heads East
item.description: Tornadoes, rain and dangerous heat leave path of destruction over Memorial Day weekend.

item.title: In Israel's North, Some Displaced Residents Call for Step Up in Fight Against Hezbollah
item.description: Nearly eight months into the war, at least 60,000 Israelis who left their homes near Lebanon in October are still displaced.

item.title: An Oil-Patch Brawl Over a $53 Billion Megadeal Entwines the Legacies of Three CEOs
item.description: The leaders of Exxon Mobil, Chevron and Hess are duking it out over a generational oil discovery in Guyana.

item.title: End of Japan's Battle Against Deflation in Sight, BOJ Deputy Gov. Says
item.description: Japan is likely close to completely overcoming its decades-long deflation, according to Bank of Japan Deputy Gov. Shinichi Uchida.

item.title: China's Industrial Profit Rose as Stimulus Measures Kicked In
item.description: Industrial profit rose in April, reversing a decline from the previous month, as Beijing’s stimulus measures started to kick in and foreign demand for Chinese products improved.

item.title: More »
item.description: Here&#x27;s what entry-level jobs really look like today

item.title: After the OceanGate Implosion, the Ultra Wealthy Still Can't Resist the Deep Sea
item.description: Makers of luxury submarines braced for collapse after an expedition to the Titanic wreckage ended in disaster. But some deep-pocketed clients are still calling.
